meta_data.title: Dynamic Hawkes Process for Modeling Diffusion Processes
meta_data.abstract: This paper presents a novel Hawkes process framework referred to as Dynamic Hawkes Process (DHP), designed to model and predict diffusion processes across communities. The work introduces a flexible latent dynamics function to capture multi-dimensional mirco-dynamic states within communities. Extensive real-world datasets demonstrate the superior performance of the DHP model compared with existing methods.

relate work.related papers: - Mohler et al. (2011), Weiss et al. (2013), Lasko et al. (2014), Bacry et al. (2015), Farajtabar et al. (2017), Isham (1979), Zhao et al. (2015), Embrechts et al. (2011)
relate work.comparisons with related methods: Compared with standard temporal point processes, our proposed model integrates dynamic community state factors using neural network architecture, unlike classical approaches which often overlook these aspects.

high_level_summary.summary of this paper: This paper proposes the Dynamic Hawkes Process (DHP), which extends traditional Hawkes processes by incorporating latent community dynamics to better predict and model diffusion processes.
high_level_summary.research purpose: To develop a model that can effectively capture and utilize the evolving dynamics of communities for better prediction of diffusion events.
high_level_summary.research challenge: Existing models inadequately capture the time-evolving nature of community states impacting diffusion processes.
high_level_summary.method summary: Incorporates latent dynamics function and extends Hawkes' triggering kernel with neural network structures for increased modeling flexibility.
high_level_summary.conclusion: The DHP provides improved performance in diffusion modeling tasks across various domains by flexibly accounting for community state dynamics.

Method.description: DHP extends traditional Hawkes models by introducing a latent dynamics function reflecting underlying community states and a flexible neural network-based kernel for modeling diffusion patterns.
Method.model: The model uses a latent dynamics function with a triggering kernel modified to account for time-evolving community states, utilizing neural network-based architectural designs.

Experiments.results: \textsf{DHP} outperformed previous models in terms of negative log-likelihood (NLL) and mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) across all tested datasets.

conclusion.summary: The paper introduces a novel Dynamic Hawkes Process that learns community state dynamics to model and predict diffusion processes, outperforming existing methods.
conclusion.future work: Future extensions will consider pairwise community dynamics and further refine assumptions for broader applicability.
